testimony: Mr Chairman, may I suggest that we take the luncheon adjournment now, so we can rearrange our seating this side and start at quarter to two?

I see it's quarter to one, if we can then take, it will probably be convenient at this stage, we'll take the lunch adjournment through till quarter to two.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION
Yes thank you.  Mr van Eck.
Thank you, Mr Chairman, I'm calling Mr Botha.

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Botha, you are an applicant here before the Committee, you are applying for amnesty, is that correct?
Could you tell us briefly, your school career, where did you complete your school career?
I matriculated from DF Malan in 1979 and I joined the Police College in Brixton in Johannesburg.
And during that period in time did you come to know Mr Barnard?
I had already know Mr Barnard before '79.  If my memory serves me correctly, I think that I already met him in 1976/'77.
He had a younger brother who played rugby with me and due to this rugby connection we had contact.  As a school pupil I had already worked with him when he was attached to the Narcotic Bureau.
And after school, what did you do?
I matriculated in 1979 and then I went to RAU where among others I studied for a B.Ed Degree.
Did you maintain contact with Mr Barnard?
We ran into each other on an on-off basis.
And when you were at RAU, did you continue with rugby?  Did you see Mr Barnard there?
I didn't see him there but I did continue with rugby.
And while we are on the topic of your rugby, what other sports did you participate in?
I had provincial colours in judo and rugby.
And when you say provincial colours in judo and rugby, could you elaborate on that briefly?

I had Northern Transvaal colours in Judo as well as Transvaal colours.  I was a champion for a number of years.  I played my first provincial rugby match when I was in standard four, I played for the Transvaal Craven Week.  Subsequently I played on all  the representative teams of Transvaal to the senior level and I played my last match during the Lion Cup Final in 1994, or rather, 1993.
Did you play foreign rugby at any point?
Yes I did, I played in France, in Hong Kong and I also went to Israel on a tour.
And after your student days you joined the police.
It was approximately in 1981, in the middle of 1981.
Could you briefly sketch your police career for us.

I joined the South African Police as a student in the Security Branch in John Vorster Square.  Afterwards I was at the Police College in 1982 and I returned to the Security Branch in John Vorster Square, where I qualified as a demolitions expert. 	In the middle of 1987 I requested a transfer to Brixton Murder and Robbery, where I was until my discharge in 1988.
And when did you complete the demolitions course?
I underwent a course in 1983 and an advance course in 1985.
Among others, the disarming of bombs.  During my period with the Security Branch the country was in a state of chaos and it was my task to disarm bombs and other types of explosive devices.
What sort of limpet mines are there?
There are two types, the SPM limpet mine which has 950 grams of explosives, then there is the 158 which contains approximately 340 grams of explosives.
Very well, we will return to that later.  You requested to be transferred to Brixton Murder and Robbery.
Is it because they were looking for demolitions experts at that unit?
Yes, that is correct, that is one of the reasons.  It was also a specialised unit which enjoyed much prestige and I wanted to continue my services there.
Before you were transferred, did you know Staal Burger, Chap Marais and Slang van Zyl?
No, I did not know them.  Coincidentally I ran into them at the scene of an explosion where they were trespassing, and that is how I came to know them.
And after you were transferred to Brixton Murder and Robbery, did you come to know these persons on a more intimate social level?
Yes, coincidentally I was with Mr van Zyl and Mr Marais' group, they were established Detectives at Brixton Murder and Robbery.
At a certain point there was movement at Brixton Murder and Robbery, where it had to do with Staal Burger.
Did you have anything to do with it?
Later Mr Burger made certain requests to you.
And we know now and I think it is common cause that it gave rise to the recruitment of members of the police to work at the CCB.
You've heard the evidence of among others, Slang van Zyl, Verster and Burger and so forth, regarding how the CCB's Region 6 came to be.  Do you agree in general terms with that evidence?
Could you briefly state, if you can recall, in what order you were recruited.
Mr Marais was recruited by Mr Burger, after that it was me and then it was Mr van Zyl.
And I think it is also common cause that among others, you had an interview with Mr Verster, there were salary negotiations and certain packages were offered.
Did you then formally resign from the police?
And all of you went to work for Mattheysen Bus Services?
Yes, that was our front when we were recruited into the CCB.
And it is common cause that during your time at Mattheysen a course was presented.
It was a Defence Force farm.
Very generally, what was the nature and scope of that training?

The objectives of the organisation were set out in more comprehensive terms, the objectives regarding what we were supposed to promote in terms of our involvement with the organisation.  This was discussed at length.  Among others, there were also forms that we had to study and everything that was based upon the CCB's plan, we had to examine all these aspects.
You were also informed regarding the various plans that had to be followed, the process of establishment, the use of false names and so forth.
Yes, that was the red and the blue plan respectively.
And what was the form of address among the members of the CCB?  After you went over to the CCB, what was the form of address among your members?
The only person who insisted upon being addressed as a Mister or a Colonel was Mr Burger, the rest were all addressed by their first names, not their false names but their first names.
And during your time at Mattheysen, how did you address Mr Burger?
Most of the times as Colonel, sometimes and Mister.
What was your rank when you left Brixton?
I'm not certain, I was either a Detective-Warrant Officer or a Detective-Sergeant.  I did not study my discharge certificate that closely.  I think it was Detective-Sergeant.
Was the CCB a private organisation or what sort of organisation was it?
It was a covert organisation which resorted under the South African Defence Force.  It was an organisation, once again, which was directly connected to the State, to the government of the day.
Thus you were still in State service but simply in a different organisation.
You salary, medical benefits, pension, did you still receive these benefits on a monthly basis?
Yes, in the form of cash.
We also heard that there were vehicle allowances and so forth, did you receive these?
And all this money that you received, who paid it out to you?
It was primarily channelled through Mattheysen Bus Services, the company for which we worked during our first phase of establishment with the CCB, however, the money came from the Defence Force.
And also the CCB name has a civil connotation, did you ever doubt at any stage that you were busy with anything other than a State institution?
We have heard of a cooling off period of approximately six months which had to be undertaken, during which there wasn't much movement.
And during that six month period, did you visit the former South West Africa?

It was to monitor SWAPO and to see what the current climate in the country was at the time of my visit, and then I had to give a feedback report to my region, to my cell, or to Mr Burger more specifically.
We have heard that presentations had to be made and that approval had to be gained for the South West Africa/Namibia or yours, did you make such submissions?
An amount was budgeted and basically by means of an administration submission, a budget was allocated to me.
Can you recall who told you to go there?

In all probability it was Mr Wouter Basson or Staal Burger.  I must just add that I initiated the whole thing to a great extent, it was during our establishment phase, it was more-or-less a general discussion in the media, the whole question surrounding Namibian independence and SWAPO and so forth.
Just to return to the phase of establishment, what was the plan, what did you have to establish?
My blue plan was established in a CC called Cabot International, it was a promotions company which among others, would distribute promotional items bearing company logos.
Sorry, could you just repeat the name of the CC.
It is Cabot International, Sir, C-a-b-o-t International.
And what would the CC have to do?
We had to distribute promotional items for companies.
You went to South West Africa, you went to Namibia at least, you returned, what did you say and what did you do?

I returned and during a cell meeting I informed the relevant parties that SWAPO was going to win the election and if we wanted to play any kind of role in South West, we would have to take definite steps in order to be able to do so.
And who were these parties that you informed?
Mr Botha, we are referring to incidents which took place more than 11 years ago, did you keep a journal and file of what you did during these times?
What was the reaction when you stated that the election would most probably not go as it had been hoped for or planned for?

It was not favourably received, among others it was said that perhaps I'd visited the wrong country and that the manner in which I had set it out was not correct and that SWAPO was not going to win the election.
It was also mentioned in discussions that more definite action had to be taken.
At any point thereafter up to this moment, did you have anything to do with the election there, with any actions there?
We've had evidence here from Mr Barnard, indicating how he went there and so forth, you personally, were you involved in any way in any matter which had to do with foreign countries?
After the six month cooling period, various regions were allocated to every one of you.

I think I should just clarify this matter somewhat more.  A region was never rigidly applied, persons would be allocated to a region but that did not prevent us from operating in other regions.  The Transvaal region was allocated to me.
And that stage, when the region was allocated to you, were you still well known in sports circles?
You were a well known figure.
Your friend at that stage, Mr Barnard, what was his position?

He had just been released from a prison sentence that he had served and he had been working at an insurance brokerage as an assessor, we met each other at a certain point and told each other that we were attached to the same structure, and upon that basis we struck up a friendship.
Let's be more specific.  You said that you informed each other that you were attached to the same structure, were these direct admissions or roundabout admissions?

I had the feeling that Mr Barnard was trying to recruit me, I had the same idea with him and before we wasted each other's time even further, we told each other where we were working.  We had already established a relationship of trust since 1977, I knew that he had been in the police when I was a school pupil.  We took each other into confidence.
Did you have any further rugby connections at that stage?
Yes, we did, every day we practised together in the gym, we also went jogging together and we also played rugby for the same club.
He stated that at that stage you were the Captain of the first team.
And on a daily basis you re-established contact with him.
Can you recall which region or division was allocated to Mr Barnard?
Were you requested at any point to assist with the testing of certain unconscious members who would be recruited?
Could you elaborate on that for us very briefly.

During January 1989, I went with Mr van Zyl to the Cape for the recruitment of unconscious members.  At the time of this visit we recruited Peaches Gordon, among others, I also tried to recruit a Coloured man, but it was unsuccessful.  During a follow-up visit we tested Peaches Gordon by means of an exercise which Mr van Zyl devised in order to test his credibility.
Did you assist Mr van Zyl, therefore?
And was Mr Burger ever in the Cape during that time?
During the initial recruitment he was in the Cape.
Mr Marais was not there, he had gone to Natal as far as you were concerned.
Did you have any further work related contact with him?
The only contact we had was purely during cell meetings and where meetings were held with regard to salaries and during our establishment period.
Regarding cell meetings, how regularly did they take place?

It is impossible to attach a specific time to these meetings, they took place quite regularly.  We gathered together on a regular basis.  In our initial time at Mattheysen, we spent time together on a daily basis.
You mentioned a Coloured man that you tried to recruit, could you elaborate on that.
I cannot even attach a name to a face, it was a Coloured man who I attempted to recruit at that time in Cape Town.  It never materialised.
Did you recruit anybody else in the Johannesburg environment?

During April, I once again tried to recruit a Coloured man by the name of Geoffrey, I was successful in my recruitment and we had an arrangement that he would gather information for me and that I would commensurately reward him.
And in terms of this cooling off phase certain names were given to you.
With the exception that the name Frank Chikane was allocated to you, did you at any stage do anything definite with regard to him?
We have heard of certain attempts which were made to kill him with poison ...(intervention)

Sorry, just before you proceed Mr van Eck.
	You say the names Frank Chikane and Bruce White were given to you, by whom and why?
It was during a regional cell meeting, every one of us received names to monitor and to collect information on and then most probably to devise a project on.

Based upon the objectives of the organisation it would maximal disruption of the enemy, not necessarily the murder of a person, it would depend upon the case and that would lead to our decision regarding any project that may emanate from the information.
It was the Co-ordinator, Wouter Basson.
With the exception of the names, did you have any further information regarding these persons?
Yes, I did.  If I recall correctly I had a photograph and an address.
Just to return to Frank Chikane, we are aware that later attempts were made to kill him, do you have any knowledge of this?
Were you involved in this in any way?
Was the Frank Chikane project ever removed from you formally?
Do you know why any other person continued with Frank Chikane?
Were you ever informed whether or not there was a reason, did you ever try to establish a reason pertaining to anything that was done by somebody else?
And while we are on the name of Bruce White, did you take any definite action regarding Bruce White?
I did, I tried to collect information on him, I identified an address and I conducted observation at this address.
In your amnesty application which was compiled we find that you are applying for the Athlone bomb explosion.
Which took place on the 31st of August 1989.
We do not find that any application has been made for Bruce White.
And also not for Frank Chikane.
We will return to that later.  But at this stage, Mr Barnard indicated that it was his impression that Bruce White had fall.

I cannot elaborate on that, perhaps that was his personal impression and perhaps it was also based upon the objectives of the organisation.  Our observation at this particular address was for the purposes of collecting information.
We will return to Bruce White later, but this was an incident in which you and Barnard were involved in June 1989, and you were also arrested for it.
No, we were not arrested as such, we were asked to report to Brixton for questioning.
And this held certain consequences for you and Mr Barnard, this action with Bruce White.
With the exception of Bruce White, did you in your division and the Coloured man later, have any success with regard to projects that you executed and so forth?

Yes, I did, but there was an advantage and a disadvantage of being known in the region.  The advantage would be that one would have greater access with regard to certain places, but the disadvantage was also that due to one's profile one could not hypothetically use another name, it wouldn't work in the particular region where one would be so well known.  I did launch further projects, Anton Rosscam.
The Rosscam project, was it registered?
Was it considered on an in-house level?
Were any amounts of money approved for this?
The project would have involved the burning of Mr Rosscam's vehicle.
What purpose would this have served?

He was quite a well known person and he used his vehicle on a daily basis, and at that stage it was about maximal disruption and we wanted to put him in a position where he could not move about freely, that is why we burnt his vehicle.
With the exception of his vehicle which had to be burnt, were there any other plans pertaining to Mr Rosscam?
And was the submission only about the burning of his vehicle?
And who initially was the subject, or who was the person that would do it?
Was this the so-called unconscious member?
Yes, he was an unconscious member.
Was that project ever executed by Geoffrey?
The project was executed but not by Geoffrey.
Mr Barnard and I decided at a certain point that Geoffrey would not perform to our wishes, that we might have overestimated his capacities and that we ourselves would continue with the project.
We have heard the evidence of Mr Barnard regarding how you broke into the vehicle and poured the petrol into the vehicle and how the vehicle was burnt, do you agree with it?
To a great extent.  I'm not certain of the hammer, but to a great extent I would agree with his version.
And if you say not necessarily the 4 pound hammer, is it that you cannot recall it or is it a case of it not having taken place?
Yes, it took place, it is just that his recollection is perhaps better than mine, I cannot attach a mass to the hammer as such.
Rosscam was never - or you never applied for the Rosscam incident.
Who dealt with your amnesty applications?
Mr Piet du Plessis from the attorneys firm, David Botha, Du Plessis and Kruger.
We heard from Mr Barnard that he first dealt with other attorneys, did you also have other attorneys before this?
Was Mr du Plessis your attorney right through this?
Can you tell the Honourable Committee why you did not apply for Rosscam.

Sir, when we compiled our applications we had a senior attorney, Etienne du Toit, and we were advised that it was not a human rights violation and I therefore do not have to apply for amnesty for this.
Did you accept it as such?
Did you at that stage have any reason to doubt it?
If you were advised to do something else would you have applied for the Rosscam incident?

Sorry, just before you get of that incident, Mr van Eck.
	You keep mentioning this term "maximum disruption", did you consider yourself personally, that the burning of Mr Rosscam's car constituted maximum disruption?

Yes it was motivated on the hand of the specific circumstances surrounding this person.  It was also part of the project that it would be a maximum disruption in his life, in the execution of his career, his daily activities and movements.

Because it would seem it would probably have been nothing more than an annoying inconvenience, I mean he can go and hire a car or borrow a motor car, I mean it's hardly a maximum disruption.  I mean his car could have broken down, it wouldn't have been a maximum disruption.

As the organisation's objectives read, the disruption could be the breaking of a window up to the killing of a person and this incident was in-between the two.  For us it was enough to disrupt him.  The project led to this.
It's just that I'm interested in the term "maximum disruption", you always seem to use the term "maximum disruption".

Sorry, Mr van Eck.
	What was your specific object in doing that, in smashing this car up?  I mean you've said maximal disruption but that's a euphemism, what was your actual object?

Mr Lax, amongst other things, to bring across a message that he is busy with activities that are to the government's detriment and whoever he may then connect with this act would then disrupt him in terms of his personal activities as the SR member of Wits.  That was our idea.
So you were trying to intimidate him, to put it plainly?
Mr Botha, while we are dealing with this maximal disruption, did this differ from person to person?

Apart from Rosscam, which was a project that you presented, or maybe not executed in the right way, but it took place in September, did you within Region 6 execute any other projects that you personally made submissions for, held an in-house meeting, got approval for and completed?
At a certain stage you were in a discussion with Mr Barnard who approached you to assist him in an observation of Dr Webster.
It was, if my recollection is correct, it was in April of '89.
Did you at that stage know that Mr Barnard worked for the same organisation but just in a different region or in a different capacity?
I knew that he was involved in the same organisation, yes.  I was not quite sure about his region, but I knew that he was involved in the organisation.
What was in Region 6, what was your relationship with Mr Burger at that stage?

Sir, we had a few confrontations that led to certain personal differences or an argument between the two of us.  In short, I said we had personality clash.  It may seem a bit childish to say that I felt that he did not give me enough attention, but that's what it boiled down to.
If you say that you felt left out, does this mean that you felt that the daily activities in Region 6 were shared with you?
No, I did not expect it, but I just got the feeling and it was just a feeling that I personally had, that I was not involved and I did not receive all the advantages.
You were approached by Mr Barnard to assist him in the Webster case, did you know Dr Webster at that stage?
No, I did not know him, but I did know that he was a high profile left-wing activist.  If I can put it in that way.
What did Ferdi Barnard say to you?  It was Dr Webster, and what was the end objective?

Mr Barnard approached me in April where he showed me an A4 photograph of Dr Webster, as well as two addresses, together with a file and an investigative journal that we use stating the dates of visits and what occurred there.  He, amongst other things, explained to me Dr Webster's involvement in left-wing organisations as well as the recruitment of students for underground structures.  He also stated that there was an incident in which Mr Webster was involved in Mozambique and where he disclosed certain information and that he got the instruction to eliminate Dr Webster.

Once again in context, I trusted Mr Barnard and I do not want to place this outside of, not put it into perspective, but we did trust each other.  Apart from our friendship, I believed what he said, he conveyed certain facts to me that correlated with what we did in the organisation and based on what he told me, I made the inference that he did receive approval from the highest level in terms of the execution of this operation and I did not question it.
Was it at any stage necessary for you, whether it was through your action or what Mr Barnard told you, to doubt what he said?
The activities or the way in which you worked before, was it necessary for you to question that?

I verified it by means of a conversation that we had, where he mentioned to me that the in-house and the presentation took place in the Ponti House.  He conveyed certain facts to me that made sense, because I was also knowledgeable concerning an in-house meeting and I did not question it, no.

I also did not question that, I was also at the Ponti Building where we drove with one vehicle and he said to me that he attended a meeting, I cannot recall his exact words, where he went into the Ponti Building and I waited downstairs for him.
Did he mention the name Verster?
We have heard of two Mr Versters, which name did he give you?
Is this the same Joe Verster who you met in your capacity in the CCB?
What did he mention about Joe Verster?

Mr Barnard said that an in-house was held concerning the operation or project, information that he collected over a period of time and that he conveyed to Mr Verster, as well as his Co-ordinator, Mr Lafras Luitingh, who was unknown to me, who handled him or who served as his Co-ordinator, and he presented the project to Mr Verster and Mr Verster basically gave him the approval with regard to the execution of the project.
Did the name Lafras Luitingh ring any bells?
You said that it was a person that was unknown to you.
Did you receive information that Lafras Luitingh was also involved in the CCB?
Mr Barnard presented him as his Co-ordinator, he could have used the word handler, but it's got basically the same profile.
You cannot specifically recall the exact words?
Did you deem it necessary Mr Botha, to question that which you were involved in with Mr Barnard, to take this up with people in your region?

I could not because it was against the rules and with the activities of the CCB, which I accepted, and we also had a very unique situation between myself and Mr Barnard and it would have been impossible to share this with my region or with my cell members.
Would you, for example, have mentioned it to Burger or Basson?  What do you think their reaction would be?
It would not have been a very good reaction.  I think it's an understatement if I put it that way.  It would have led to my immediate dismissal.
What do you think would be the results or the consequences if the operation was executed in the elimination of Dr Webster and if you've mentioned this to Dr Webster?
Well they would have suspended the operation or the project.
What did you do in terms of the execution of this project of Mr Barnard?

Well generally Mr Barnard and myself monitored or visited Dr Webster's house.  I think it was three or four times, I would say it was four times.  We monitored movements and to see if he appeared and certain opportunities, I think it was the 1st of May 1989 Mr Barnard came to pick me up at my residence in a white vehicle and we again followed the normal routine to the monitoring of the house and the observation that took place there and on that specific day Dr Webster drove past us in a white pick-up or bakkie and Mr Barnard felt that this was the ideal moment to execute the project and he continued and eliminated the person with a sawed-off shotgun.  I acted as the driver of the vehicle and that was in general my participation in the project.
Mr Botha we have heard the evidence of how Mr Barnard went to go and practice with somebody else's shotgun were you involved in that preparation?
Were you involved in the preparation of the shotgun?
Every time when you went to go and observe the house were you ready, if the opportunity comes up to execute this operation?
Yes we were prepared and ready every single time we went.
Did you make use of balaclavas?
Yes it was in the vehicle.  During the execution of the operation we also covered our faces with it.
Was there any other opportunity in which Mr Barnard could shoot Dr Webster?
Not what I know of, not where I accompanied him.  I did hear that he did observe the house at other times but not when I was with there.
Were you involved in the writing down of the details?
No.  In short it was his project.  I assisted him as a confidante if I can explain it in that way.
After the shooting of Dr Webster were you dropped off at your house and Mr Barnard left with the evidence, do you know what happened to it?

No Sir, he just said that he broke the shotgun into pieces.  I also again did not question his integrity or in terms of what he told me.  Once again we had this trust between the two of us but I would doubt that he held the weapon at his house, for example.
On that specific day there was a lady with Dr Webster, did you see her?
Mr Barnard told us what his initial attitude was towards this Commission, how he approached this Commission, and his initial attitude was that he is here but he will not cooperate.

That is correct.  People who know Mr Barnard will know that he's a difficult person to get along with.  He's a difficult witness and he is also a person who has got a history as far back as his first detention that he never implicated anybody else.

The reason why I am asking you this is that Mr Barnard explained to us that why at the previous sitting he systematically started changing his attitude towards the Commission to the approach and sympathy that came especially from Mrs Omar and that this resulted into a change of mind and on which he then decided to take this Commission into his confidence.
Yes I was party to this and I did observe it and was part of it, that is correct.

Right.  It is common cause and I will ask you on this a bit later and certainly you will be asked by other parties concerning this, you were asked about why you denied any participation in the Webster murder.  It was put to you that you made a statement to the Attorney General, Mr Pretorius, which included your involvement in the Webster murder.
It was in February last year.
In other words it was a long time before Mr Barnard had a change of heart with regards to admitting to the murder of Dr Webster?

That is correct, yes.  As Mr Barnard testified I visit him on a regular basis in C-Max in Pretoria and at a certain stage I had a conversation in which I told him at a certain stage he will have to draw a line.  I am part of the reconciliation process.  At the end of the day, apart from the deeds that we committed I also have a conscience and I just want to clear my conscience, and I was approached by the Attorney General, Mr Pretorius, and I told him this is what I feel.  I want to do this.  And he supported me.  And he also said to me that he was not going to open his heart, if I can put it that way, but this is my right to do what I want to, and that is what I then did.
Up to the time when you made contact with Mr Pretorius was Mr du Plessis your legal representative?
This is now from the beginning of the CCB and the revelations that happened throughout this process?
During that process while you spoke to Mr Pretorius were you still with Mr du Plessis, as a client of his?

Yes Sir.  Just before I made a statement I felt that because of ethical reasons it would not be correct to place his integrity in doubt, there would be a clash of interests, I then decided to get a different legal team to represent me.
Is it correct that when you changed your legal team you did not inform Mr du Plessis what the reason was?  You did not disclose the Webster incident to him?
Is there a reason for this?

Sir I had never discussed Webster with anybody, it was a closed book.  I saw that Verster and other CCB, I saw how they reacted during my detention and the day after the shooting he asked people if we were involved and that made me realise that this project would not be admitted, either by himself or by any other party.  So it was a closed book.
Sorry Mr Botha, when you made this statement to Mr Pretorius, was that after the conclusion of Mr Barnard's trial, after he had been convicted of the murder of Dr Webster?

So why did you elect to make a statement to the Attorney General's office, what was the purpose?  Was it just to purge yourself, to come clean in the spirit of reconciliation or was there some other reason as to why you went to the Attorney General in particular, the Attorney General's office?

Sir they approached me.  I also went to them with regards to another incident that had nothing to do with the Commission's proceedings, and they also asked me to make a statement in this regard.  The seed was planted and I started thinking about this and struggling with it and I felt that here's an opportunity to come clean and I just then applied myself to it.
You never applied for amnesty for the death of Mr Webster?
The post mortem inquest was held.
On both occasions you decided not to make known what your role was?
Did you have any personal knowledge of the instructions given to Mr Barnard?  Did you trust his word?
Why did you continually deny your part in it or to tell the truth, why did you lie all this time?

Sir I will put it to you again, that it was Mr Barnard's project and that I could not take responsibility for something that he had no protection of.  It was very clear that he stood alone.  I was a bystander or outsider, somebody who just assisted him in the execution of the project and I could not disclose the project.  So that was my viewpoint.
With the Harms Commission and the investigation that took place there who covered your legal costs?
It was after you were arrested in terms of Section 29?
Did any person with a rank, did they tell you to keep quiet?
Brigadier Krappies Engelbrecht.  He was accompanied by Brigadier van Rensburg while I was detained in Hartebeesfontein.
What was your expectation from the structure of the CCB during the Harms Commission proceedings?

Sir it was very clear that during our training it was presented to us that we would get indemnity for the acts that we commit and it became clear to me that we will not get the protection from the generals and staff and that it came from a level above them, the politicians, and we were told that what is on the table now we will talk about and we kept to that.
Did you see how your good friend Mr Barnard was dealt with?
Yes I did see how they dealt with him.
Did he say anything to you concerning the Dr Webster incident with regards to disclosure?
No Sir, because we saw how Mr Verster and Lafras Luitingh dealt with him it was not negotiable that we would say anything about it.  It would have been a very bad reflection on us.
